title: How did the ideas of the enlightenment lead to revolution? - Quora

response.answer_text: They didn't. They were the expression of a bourgeois class in it's cradle by itself and in itself. This bourgeois class, in it's adolescence, in a struggle against an aging and blind nobility, made a deal with the monarchies of Europe so that it could develop it's own strength while giving support to absolutism. When the bourgeois class was, then, in it's young adulthood, it took on assault the nobility and won, creating the bourgeois society from which we live it's consequences from until this day. Meanwhile, the ideas of enlightenment were the very expressions of such class on justifying itself for itself and for the struggle to come. It weren't the ideas who made the enlightenment, it was the bourgeoisie.
